content:
Hi Jay,

This is a peer-to-peer support forum for users, not a place to make a special request of developers. It's unlikely that developers would respond to such a request. There is another place to suggest features, but there's no need to have a Thunderbird function for importing a large profile. You can just move files through the file system.

Before proceeding, would you please say more about your current set-up and what you want to accomplish?
creator: mozilla98

content: Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles, Create a New Profile, Choose Folder..., browse to the unzipped Profile folder.
creator: sfhowes

content: I have read thousands of words about how to do it and I’m still irritated because I can’t. My problems started when Thunderbird did an unwanted update and then wanted me to create a new profile. My wife was dying and I’m almost 90 years old.. I’ve tried using the add-on app, but it won’t handle 20 GB. It appeared to import a bit of my profile and then quit. Once an old profile is put into the right place in the Thunderbird folder, how do I get to it.? I read about the profile.INI file. Do I need to modify that? I did a new install after saving the old profile hoping that might work, but it left me still confused. I had trouble getting the SMPT settings, incoming and outgoing settings. Finally have that working. I tried to use the slowest changing version of Thunderbird. I donated money to Thunderbird, but I’ll never do it again because they started changing everything.
creator: JayinOK

content:
sfhowes said
Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles, Create a New Profile, Choose Folder..., browse to the unzipped Profile folder.

sfhowes, the "choose folder" function sets where the new profile will be created. How does browsing to the unzipped profile folder there help? Isn't it better to keep all the profiles in the profiles folder? How should Jay import a profile? Does he have to import at all? His old profile is probably still in his profiles folder, just not in use because of possible incompatibility with an upgrade.
creator: mozilla98

content: The source profile can be anywhere. Place it in the standard location if desired. 'Creating' the profile this way avoids editing the profiles.ini file and guarantees it will be read by TB. If the old profile is still readable by TB, it can be launched from about:profiles. As long as it wasn't created by a newer version of TB than the one installed, it should be readable by the current TB.
creator: sfhowes

content:
'

sfhowes said

The source profile can be anywhere. Place it in the standard location if desired. 'Creating' the profile this way avoids editing the profiles.ini file and guarantees it will be read by TB. If the old profile is still readable by TB, it can be launched from about:profiles. As long as it wasn't created by a newer version of TB than the one installed, it should be readable by the current TB.

Thanks. I'm still not seeing the connection between creating a new profile and using the old profile, so I'm guessing that Jay may not see it either. And I'd like to know exactly how to guide him. What I have so far is this:

  1. Move the old profile into the profiles directory.
  2. Create a new profile in the profiles directory.

OK, now there are two profiles in the profiles directory that didn't used to be there. What's next? Isn't there a step for importing the old profile into the newly created profile or something similar?

Then set the preferred profile as the default.

If the old profile is still readable by TB, it can be launched from about:profiles. As long as it wasn't created by a newer version of TB than the one installed, it should be readable by the current TB.

So can Jay just go to about:profiles and set his old profile as the default? If there are no compatitbility issues, why did Thunderbird create a new profile? Or are you talking about the old profile after some kind of process to import it into the newly created profile?

content: Try change the filter to from contains bobp and another line for from does not contain bobp@ncqkll.com Then, if a message from any sender using bobp, but not from bobp@ncqkll.com, it would be processed via the filter. That allows you to send to yourself when needed.
creator: davidsk

content:
If you used the tools>export feature to move the profile, all passwords are removed for security. I always suggest using the OS's file copy facility to achieve that when passwords are to be retained: Here are sample steps:

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird - IMPORTANT
  4. you are now in the profile folder. copy ALL of it and save to external media
  5. install thunderbird on new PC, if not already done
  6. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  7. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  8. exit thunderbird
  9. you are in the profile. Paste what you copied here ########
  10. restart thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content:
Riporta esattamente il messaggio di errore che ricevi.

Più in generale, Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto
creator: @next

content:
Thunderbird is rich in its offerings for fonts, and it is important to follow the steps to get exactly what you want. I put the steps in this prior post: 

  https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1462509

Note: Remember that your font settings can be for you AND recipients, or just for you. The indication in my article is that fonts are for you, the sender, as the recipient may not appreciate your preferences. It's your decision, obviously. Good luck. Let me know how it goes.
creator: davidsk

content:
Just found the problem, actually straightforward, but the root cause is a concern.

The mailing list name is fine with spaces in it. What I stupidly hadn't noticed was that my mailing lists have actually lost all their contents. Once I edit the lists and add back in all of the previous addresses, everything works fine again.

What I still can't explain is why my mailing lists lost their contents?

Maybe I need to backup all my mailing lists so that I can easily restore them if this issue happens again.
creator: 168subs1

content:
To get the formatting bar, go to 'account settngs' , click the account in left side bar, then the 'composition&addressing' link, and tick to compose in HTML The other option is to press the shift key when clicking the 'new message' button

to permanently set the HTML signature, go to 'account settings' pane and click the account name in left sidebar. the composition window will be on the right.

If you want to edit HTML while in compose window, I encourage using the ThunderHTMLedit addon at https://www.betterbird.eu/addons/
creator: davidsk

content:
Wow, Problem located, but Unbelievable! A brand-name software in the VPN world, NordVPN, which we unfortunately bought a 2 years subscription from (a big write off!), is the guilty party! Once you start that untested intrusive and resources grabbing software, even without enabling any VPN connection, Thunderbird is messed up! Thunderbird start up, properly with profile manager, takes 4-6 sec to connect w/o NordVPN running Thunderbird takes 5-7 min, and profile manager will not be started, once NordVPN was started and you logged in (but w/o VPN enabled. A half hour chat with NordVPN resulted in zero resolution. but the request to run dozens of test for them. Testing is job of a software company, not the paying customer!

Summary: Do NOT use NordVPN with Thunderbird!
creator: info2511
